question: 3 (c)
sols_html:
In the previous question, we showed that for some \(c\) in the interval \((0,b)\)

\[\begin{aligned} \cos(c) = \frac{\sin(b)}{b}\end{aligned}\]

Now we know that for all possible values of \(c\), \(\cos(c)\) is bounded above by 1, or

\[\begin{aligned} \cos(c) \leq 1\end{aligned}\]

Substituting what we know from part (b), this is the same as

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{\sin(b)}{b} \leq 1\end{aligned}\]

Because \(b > 0\) we can multiply both sides by b to get

\[\begin{aligned} \sin(b) \leq b\end{aligned}\]

Which completes our proof.
